oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Individual transportation order for G. Brooks, wife, and 2 daughters
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wainwright, William Alonzo, 1832-1904; United States -- Army -- Quartermaster Corps; Gillem, Alvan Cullem, 1830-1875; Coile, John Leonard; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Transportation, Military; Railroads; Refugees; Prisoners of war; War and transportation; Jefferson County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Individual Transportation Order, September 28, 1865, for Gains Brooks; Sarah, his wife; and two daughters (refugees) with a letter detailing Brooks' imprisonment after trying to cross the Cumberland Gap to reach Federal forces, the family's move west, and the attempt to return with his family to their home in Jefferson County, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: William Alonzo Wainwright, United States Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Travel was strictly monitored and curtailed during the war and into the post-war period. Both military personnel and civilians were required to apply to the Quartermaster's Department for authorization to travel by train.
